case_name: Messrs Narayanaswami Sons v. Employees State Insurance Corporation

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 14th October, 1966 of the High Court of Mysore at Bangalore in Misc. First Appeal No. 124 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 14th October, 1966 of the High Court of Mysore at Bangalore in Misc. First Appeal No. 124 of 1966.

facts.text: The appellant and his brother, Srinivasamurthy are partners of a firm carrying on the business of manufacturing and exporting of polished granite memorial stones in the name and style of Messrs Narayanaswami Sons.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his brother, Srinivasamurthy are partners of a firm carrying on the business of manufacturing and exporting of polished granite memorial stones in the name and style of Messrs Narayanaswami Sons.

facts.text: The firm is admittedly a factory both under the Factories Act as well as under the Employees State Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: The firm is admittedly a factory both under the Factories Act as well as under the Employees State Insurance Act  briefly the Act .

facts.text: The appellant claims to directly employ about 35 persons in his factory and has been paying contribution under the Act on their account.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claims to directly employ about 35 persons in his factory and has been paying companytri- bution under the Act on their account.

facts.text: Adjacent to his own factory there is another factory situated on the appellants land leased out by him to two persons, Chidambarchari and Shankarsubbachari hereinafter referred to as the contractors.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated that adjacent to his own factory there is another factory situated on the appellants land leased out by him to two persons, Chidambarchari and Shankarsubbachari  hereinafter referred to as the companytractors .

facts.text: The contractors employ about 50 workers in their factory for purposes of cutting and dressing the granite stones.

anchor.surface_text: The companytractors employ about 50 workers in their factory for purposes of cutting and dressing the granite stones.

facts.text: The lorry drivers bring granite from the surrounding areas and unload them outside the factory. The contractors get these to their portion of the leased land for cutting them.

anchor.surface_text: The lorry drivers bring granite from the surrounding areas and unload them outside the factory The companytractors get these to their portion of the leased land for cutting them.

facts.text: After cutting these are sent back to the appellants factory where these are designed and polished and thereafter exported.

anchor.surface_text: After cutting these are sent back to the appellants factory where these are designed and polished and thereafter exported.

facts.text: The Employees State Insurance Corporation applied to the Employees State Insurance Court at Bangalore for recovery of an amount of Rs. 8893/- being the employees contribution payable by the appellant for the period commencing from 27-7-1958 to 31-1-1964 on account of the workers employed by the two contractors.

anchor.surface_text: The Employees State Insurance Corporation  briefly the Corporation  applied to the Employees State Insurance Court at Bangalore  briefly the Court  for recovery of an amount of Rs. 8893/- being the employees companytribution payable by the appellant for the period companymencing from 27-7-1958 to 31-1-1964 on account of the workers employed by the two companytractors

facts.text: The Court decided against the Corporation holding that the contractors were not immediate employers within the meaning of section 2(13) of the Act and they were independent contractors and hence the appellant was not the principal employer in respect of the employees working under the contractors.

anchor.surface_text: described as immediate employers tinder the Act. The companyrt decided against the Corporation holding .that the companytractors were number immediate employers within the meaning of section 2  13  of the Act and they were independent company tractors and hence the appellant was number the principal employer in respect of the employees working under the companytractors.

facts.text: The Corporation appealed to the High Court of Mysore against the aforesaid order under section 82(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation appealed to the High Court of Mysore against the aforesaid order under section 82 2  of the Act.

facts.text: The High Court held that the appellant was the principal employer and the contractors were the immediate employers under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant was the principal employer an the companytractors were the immediate employers under the Act.

facts.text: The High Court further held that the workers under the contractors were employees within the meaning of section 2(9)(ii) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further held that the workers under the companytractors were employees within the meaning of section 2  9   ii  of the Act.

facts.text: The High Court thus accepted the appeal of the Corporation. Hence this appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thus accepted the appeal of the Corporation. Hence this appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Before the Court evidence was given by both sides.

anchor.surface_text: Before the companyrt evidence was given by both sides and the following findings of the companyrt are adverted to by the High Court .

facts.text: All that can be said to have been proved by the applicant Corporation in this case is that RWs 2 and 3 the contractors work at a place belonging to the respondent and execute part of the work which is necessary to manufacture the final finished product for sale.

anchor.surface_text: lm15 All that can be said to have been proved by the applicant companyporation in this case is that RWs 2 and 3  the company- tractors  work at a place belonging to the respondent and execute part of the work which is necessary to manufacture the final finished product for sale.

facts.text: There is evidence to show that these employees under the contractors are employed in connection with the work of the respondent-factory.

anchor.surface_text: After examining the evidence the High. Court also found as follows There is evidence to show that these employees  under ,the companytractors  are employed in companynection with the work of the respondent-facory.

facts.text: The other factory of the contractors on the leased land of the principal employer, adjoining the latters factory, is registered under the Factories Act in the year 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The other factory of the companytractors on the leased land of the principal employer, adjoining the latters factory. is registered under the Fac- tories Act in the year 1963.

facts.text: Although admittedly a factory, there is no evidence on the record that the contractors pay any contribution under the Act or have been even charged separately as principal employers so far as their so called direct employees are concerned.

anchor.surface_text: Although admittedly a factory, there is numberevidence on the record that the companytractors pay any companytribution under the Act or have been even charged separately as principal employers so far as their so called direct employees are companycerned.

facts.text: The work in the two places has an intimate connection and is a piece of an integrated whole and the said work by the contractors through their labour is ordinarily part of the work of the principal-factory undertaken by the contractors.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that on the findings of fact the work undertaken by the companytractors in the adjoining vicinity, even though their factory may have been subsequently registered under the factories Act, is preliminary or incidental to the work in the principal employer-factory turning out the finished product for export.

facts.text: Their factory is situated in the premises of the appellants factory which according to the definition clause includes the precincts thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Their factory is situated in the premises of the appellants factory which according to the definition clause includes the precincts thereof.

facts.text: The two contractors are immediate employers within the meaning of section 2(13) and the workers employed for cutting and dressing the granite stones by the immediate employers are employees within section 2(9)(ii) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It, therefore, follows that the two companytractors are immediate employers within the meaning of section 2  13  and the workers employed for cutting and dressing the granite stones by the immediate employers are employees within section 2  9   ii  of the Act, being employed through the immediate employers on the premises of the factory including the precincts thereof.

facts.text: In 1963 the contractors factory was separately registered under the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that in 1963 the companytractors factory was separately registered under the Factories Act

facts.text: The premises A and B belong to the partners. Only a wall separated the two premises. There was a connecting door which appeared to have been closed.

anchor.surface_text: The premises A and B belong to the partners. Only a wall separated the two premises. There was a companynecting door which appeared to have been closed.

anchor.surface_text: Again RW-2 also deposed that it is since last three years that, I undertook the work of the second party i.e. the appellant.

holdings.text: the principal requirement of the definition, namely, that the work or the construction is undertaken on the premises of the factory ... is satisfied in the present case on the evidence on records and we hold accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: The principal requirement of the definition, namely, that the work or the companystruction is undertaken on the premises of the factory and about which both sides join issue, is satisfied in the present case on the evidence on records and we hold accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Site plan and evidence show environmental and functional unity between portions A and B despite wall; follows Ardeshir precedent on premises including open land.

holdings.text: We are also satisfied that the workers under the contractors are employees employed by the principal employer through the immediate employers on the premises of the factory in work which is ordinarily the normal work of the factory or is, at any rate, preliminary to the work or which is certainly incidental to the purpose of the main factory of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We are also satisfied that the workers under the companytractors are employees employed by the principal employer through the immediate employers on the premises of the factory in work which is ordinarily the numbermal work of the factory or is, at any rate, preliminary to the work or which is certainly incidental to the purpose of the main factory of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of PW-1 and site plan confirm work process integration; no requirement for unity of control emphasized.

precedents.citation: Ardeshir H. Bhiwandiwala v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Ardeshir H. Bhiwandiwala v. The State of Bombay 1 dealt with the term Premises in the definition of factory under section 2 m of the Factories Act and after noticing its meaning in various Law Lexicons and dictionaries observed-

precedents.case_name: Ardeshir H Bhiwandiwala v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Meaning of 'premises' in the definition of factory under Factories Act includes land or buildings or both depending on context; generic term for open land or land with buildings or buildings alone
precedents.cited_holding: The word premises has not come to refer to either land or buildings or to both, depending on the context. It is therefore clear that the word premises is a generic term meaning open land or land with buildings or buildings alone.
